p: Though above and belowground functional traits varied among growth forms, these traits were generally not associated with their ability to compete in either soil environment, measured as either the ability to resist suppression from (competitive response, CR) or suppress (competitive effect, CE) A. petiolata ( Table 4). The only exception to this pattern was the nearly significant ( P = 0.06) positive relationship between Y(II) @ 5 weeks and competitive response in A. petiolata history soil. In addition, even though species varied in their response to soil history, this variation was also not correlated with competitive ability. The ln response ratio of growth in A. petiolata history versus control soils ( Fig. 3) was not associated with either competitive response ( F 1,25 = 0.07, r 2 = 0.003, P = 0.79, λ = 0.978) or competitive effect ( F 1,25 = 0.57, r 2 = 0.022, P = 0.45, λ = 0.266).
